entry.content:
The Setup

Problem Description

Santa is trying to deliver presents in a large apartment building, but he can’t find the right floor - the directions he got are a little confusing. He starts on the ground floor (floor 0) and then follows the instructions one character at a time.

An opening parenthesis, (, means he should go up one floor, and a closing parenthesis, ), means he should go down one floor.

The apartment building is very tall, and the basement is very deep; he will never find the top or bottom floors.

Example of Input

  • (()) and ()() both result in floor 0.
  • ((( and (()(()( both result in floor 3.
  • ))((((( also results in floor 3.
  • ()) and ))( both result in floor -1 (the first basement level).
  • ))) and )())()) both result in floor -3.

Question to Answer

To what floor do the instructions take Santa?

Getting Started - Simple Approach

I don’t know for sure, but my hypothesis about what’s happening here is that Santa’s elves have lost their minds. Over the years as the world’s human population has grown to billions of people, Santa’s elves have had to work harder and harder each year to produce presents for everyone, and they’ve finally reached their breaking point.

So instead of taking appropriate measures to provide mental healthcare to his elves, Santa has hired us to untangle the directions they have produced for him in their maddened state.

We will see what we can do.

Video

Translating the problem into code

The first step when trying to solve any kind of problem with code is determining which data structures in the code we will use to represent various things.

In this case it looks like we will at the very least need to deal with Numbers and Strings.

The floors will be represented as a number:

floor = 0

Moving up a floor can be represented by addition:

floor = floor + 1

Moving down a floor can be represented by subtraction:

floor = floor - 1

And the directions will be represented as strings:

directions = "(())"

Now we need to follow our directions one character at a time so that means we will also need to work with Arrays

directions_array = ["(", "(", ")", ")"]

Describing the solution in English

My floor starts as 0. Given some string of directions I need to:

  1. Turn that string into an array of individual characters
  2. Look at each character in the array one by one
    1. If that character is ( I need to add 1 to my floor
    2. If that character is ) I need to subtract 1 from my floor
  3. Return what floor I am on after I finish looking at all of the characters in the array.

Translating English solution into code

I can use a variable called floor to store the floor that I am on. Initially it is 0

floor = 0

In order to split up a string of directions into an array of individual characters I can use the .split method. See documentation for .split

directions_array = "(())".split("")
#=> ["(", "(", ")", ")"]

I can then use .each on that array to loop through it and adjust my floor based on one character at a time. See documentation for .each

directions_array.each do |character|
  # do something with the character
end

In order to do different things depending on what the character is, I will need to use an if statement. See documentation for if

if character == ")"
  floor = floor + 1
elsif character == "("
  floor = floor - 1
end

Putting it all together

We’re going to define a method that is going to do the work for us, and the input to that method is going to be these directions that we are getting as a string of parentheses.

def follow_directions(directions_string)
  # do stuff here
end

The first thing we are going to put inside our method is going to be the code that handles that first part of our plain english solution

Turn that string into an array of individual characters

def follow_directions(directions_string)
  directions_array = directions_string.split('')
end

The next part of our method is going to initialize the variable that is going to store what floor we are on. So we can call that variable floor and we can set it to 0 to start.

def follow_directions(directions_string)
  directions_array = directions_string.split('')
  floor = 0
end

After that we are going to start working on the second part of our plain english solution.

Look at each character in the array one by one

To do this we are going to use the .each method.

def follow_directions(directions_string)
  directions_array = directions_string.split('')
  floor = 0
  directions_array.each do |direction|
    # do stuff here
  end
end

Inside of this .each method we are going to handle the next two parts of our plain english solution.

If that character is ( I need to add 1 to my floor

If that character is ) I need to subtract 1 from my floor

We are going to accomplish this with the if statement that we talked about earlier.

def follow_directions(directions_string)
  directions_array = directions_string.split('')
  floor = 0
  directions_array.each do |direction|
    if direction == ")"
      floor = floor + 1
    elsif direction == "("
      floor = floor - 1
    end
  end
end

The final part of our method is going to take care of the last part of our plain english solution.

Return what floor I am on after I finish looking at all of the characters in the array.

def follow_directions(directions_string)
  directions_array = directions_string.split('')
  floor = 0
  directions_array.each do |direction|
    if direction == ")"
      floor = floor + 1
    elsif direction == "("
      floor = floor - 1
    end
  end
  floor
end

Testing our method

We can use the examples of inputs and outputs for this problem to test our method.

So we know that the input (()) should produce the output 0

follow_directions("(())")
#=> 0

And we know that the input (()(()( should produce the output 3

follow_directions("(()(()(")
#=> 3

When we are running our method and we want to print out the output of the method to the console we can use puts

puts follow_direcitons("(())")

This is fine for manual testing, but manual testing is tedious and error prone, so what I would like to do is write some code that will use all of the examples I have for this problem to automatically test my code for me.

Right now all of my examples are written in plain english.

  • (()) and ()() both result in floor 0.
  • ((( and (()(()( both result in floor 3.
  • ))((((( also results in floor 3.
  • ()) and ))( both result in floor -1 (the first basement level).
  • ))) and )())()) both result in floor -3.

So just like we did with the main problem, the first thing to do here is to figure out how to represent my examples as data structures in code that I can use in a program.

The first idea that comes to me is that I can represent each example as an Array. The first item in the array will be the input and the second item in the array will be the output that I expect.

For instance, the first example can be represented as:

["(())", 0]

I can then put all of these individual arrays into one big array that will hold all of my examples.

[
  ["(())", 0],
  ["()()", 0],
  ["(((", 3],
  ["(()(()(", 3],
  ["))(((((", 3],
  ["())", -1],
  ["))(", -1],
  [")))", -3],
  [")())())", -3]
]

Now let’s once again describe how this testing code is going to work in plan english.

Given an array of examples, where each example is an array where the first item is the input, and the second item is the expected output.

  1. Go through each example in the array one by one
    1. Call the method I want to test using the first part of the example as the input
    2. Check to see if the output of my method matches the output I expect, which is stored in the second part of the example
    3. If the output I get is equal to the output I expect, then my test passes
    4. If the output I get is not equal to the output I expect, then my test fails
      1. If my test fails I should print out what I expect and what I got so that I can understand why it failed.

So to take care of the first part of my plain english solution I can once again use .each

[
  ["(())", 0],
  ["()()", 0],
  ["(((", 3],
  ["(()(()(", 3],
  ["))(((((", 3],
  ["())", -1],
  ["))(", -1],
  [")))", -3],
  [")())())", -3]
].each do |test_case|
  # run tests here
end

Now each test case has two parts - the input (a set of directions as a string) and the expected output. So first I am going to pull out those two parts into their own variables.

[
  ["(())", 0],
  ["()()", 0],
  ["(((", 3],
  ["(()(()(", 3],
  ["))(((((", 3],
  ["())", -1],
  ["))(", -1],
  [")))", -3],
  [")())())", -3]
].each do |test_case|
  directions = test_case[0]
  expected = test_case[1]
end

Next I am going to call my method on the input and save the result in a variable.

[
  ["(())", 0],
  ["()()", 0],
  ["(((", 3],
  ["(()(()(", 3],
  ["))(((((", 3],
  ["())", -1],
  ["))(", -1],
  [")))", -3],
  [")())())", -3]
].each do |test_case|
  directions = test_case[0]
  expected = test_case[1]
  received = follow_directions(directions)
end

Now I can write the code that checks whether or not what I expected is equal to what I received to handle the next two parts of my plain english solution.

If the output I get is equal to the output I expect, then my test passes

If the output I get is not equal to the output I expect, then my test fails

So once again I am going to use an if statement and I am going to use puts to print the result of the test to the screen.

[
  ["(())", 0],
  ["()()", 0],
  ["(((", 3],
  ["(()(()(", 3],
  ["))(((((", 3],
  ["())", -1],
  ["))(", -1],
  [")))", -3],
  [")())())", -3]
].each do |test_case|
  directions = test_case[0]
  expected = test_case[1]
  received = follow_directions(directions)
  if expected == received
    puts 'PASSED'
  else
    puts 'FAILED'
  end
end

Now there is just one last thing to do from our plain english description.

If my test fails I should print out what I expect and what I got so that I can understand why it failed.

I can do this by using String Interpolation

[
  ["(())", 0],
  ["()()", 0],
  ["(((", 3],
  ["(()(()(", 3],
  ["))(((((", 3],
  ["())", -1],
  ["))(", -1],
  [")))", -3],
  [")())())", -3]
].each do |test_case|
  directions = test_case[0]
  expected = test_case[1]
  received = follow_directions(directions)
  if expected == received
    puts 'PASSED'
  else
    puts 'FAILED'
    puts "Expected: #{expected}"
    puts "Received: #{recevied}"
  end
end

After running all of our tests and seeing that they all pass we are ready to use our function on our puzzle input.

Running on Puzzle Input

Pasting my puzzle input into my program would be annoying to do because it is so long, so instead I am storing it in a separate file. That file is called puzzle-input.txt

I can read from that file using File.read

puzzle_input = File.read("./puzzle-input.txt")

Then I can call my method on that string that I have populated with the contents of that file.

puzzle_input = File.read("./puzzle-input.txt")
puts follow_directions(puzzle_input)

I can then paste the result of running my method on my puzzle input - 138 - into the answer input for Advent of Code to see if it is correct… and it is! So we have successfully completed part 1 of this puzzle.

entry.title: Tools - Hammerspoon
entry.content:
The Problem

Resizing windows with a mouse is annoying.

The Solution

Use the automation tool Hammerspoon

Lua

Hammerspoon scripts are written in Lua

Learn X in Y Minutes Where X=Lua

Window Grid

In .hammerspoon/init.lua

-- config reload
hs.alert.show("Config loaded")

-- animation duration
hs.window.animationDuration = 0

-- grid config
hs.grid.GRIDHEIGHT = 4
hs.grid.GRIDWIDTH = 4
hs.grid.MARGINX = 0
hs.grid.MARGINY = 0

-- manual window move screen / resize
hs.hotkey.bind({"ctrl"}, "D", function()
  hs.grid.show()
end)

Usage

  1. CTRL + D to display the grid
  2. Letter of the grid that corresponds with upper left corner of the window
  3. Letter of the grid that corresponds with lower right corner of the window

e.g.

  • Full screen: CTRL+D 1 V
  • Left half of screen: CTRL+D 1 X
  • Right half of screen: CTRL+D 3 V

entry.title: Make this website
entry.content:
What Makes a Website

HTML + CSS

Why Use a Static Site Generator?

Remove a lot of the tedium of doing the same thing over an over by hand. Use a lot of starter code that someone else has written for us so we can focus on the website content right away and slowly adjust the styles and whatnot over time.

What Static Site Generator are We Using?

Jekyll

This site is going to talk a lot about the Ruby programming language so it is only fitting that our static site generator is written in Ruby.

Initial Setup

  1. Follow the installation instructions on the Jekyll site.
  2. Initialize git repository 
    git init
git add -A
git commit -am 'Start new jekyll site'
  3. Update the _config.yml file with info about the site.
    • title, email, description, url, github_username
    • remove twitter_username
    • remove minima theme
    • add jekyll-seo-tag to plugins
  4. Update the Gemfile to include jekyll-seo-tag 
    group :jekyll_plugins do
  ...
  gem 'jekyll-seo-tag', '2.6.1'
end
  5. Copy all of the assets from the starter theme plugin (minima) into our project. See Overriding theme defaults In the terminal: 
    cp -r $(bundle show minima)/_layouts
cp -r $(bundle show minima)/_includes
cp -r $(bundle show minima)/_sass
cp -r $(bundle show minima)/assets
  6. Start updating theme defaults
    1. I’m not going to use Google Analytics
      • remove lines 8-10 in _includes/head.html
      • rm _includes/google-analytics.html
    2. I’m not going to use Disqus Comments
      • Remove lines 33-35 in _layouts/post.html
      • rm _includes/disqus_comments.html
    3. The only Social features I am going to use are Github and Youtube
      • rm _includes/icon-twitter.html _includes/icon-twitter.svg
      • Remove all of the lines that aren’t about Github, Youtue, or RSS in _includes/social.html
      • Ditto for all svg icons in assets/minima-social-icons.svg
  7. Make sure none of our changes broke anything by running bundle exec jekyll serve and visiting the site on localhost:4000
  8. Commit changes to git 
    git add -A
git commit -am 'Copy and customize Minima theme'

Changing Syntax Highlighting

Jekyll uses Rouge to do syntax highlight on blocks of code in Markdown. I am going to use the Thankful Eyes theme.

In terminal:

gem install rouge

In ruby console (irb)

File.open('_scss/minima/_syntax-highlighting.scss', 'wb') do |f| 
  f << Rouge::Themes::ThankfulEyes.render(scope: '.highlight') 
end

I like this for blocks of code but it’s too strong to apply the exact same styles to inline blocks. Instead I am going to translate the background color to rgba and set the alpha value to something less than 1 so that there’s enough of a difference to catch the eye but not too much to make it a jarring transition from the white-backgrounded text that will be right next to it.

In _scss/minima/_base.scss

pre, 
code {
  &.language-plaintext {
    background-color: rgba(22, 52, 71, 0.03);
  }
}

Changing Fonts

I like sans-serif fonts for headers but I prefer serif for body copy.

  1. In _sass/minima.scss
    • delete $base-font-family
    • add $sans-serif-font-family: sans-serif;
    • add $serif-font-family: serif;
  2. In _sass/minima/_base.scss
    • change $base-font-family to $serif-font-family in the rules for body
    • add font-family: $sans-serif-font-family to the rules for headings and anchors

Bash command to start posts

Writing posts with the correct file name and YAML frontmatter is a bit tedious so I created a shell script to do that for me.

I use zsh and Oh My Zsh so to add this function I…

  1. Navigate to ~/.oh-my-zsh/custom
  2. Create a new file called jekyll-blog.zsh and open it in my editor
  3. Write a function called new_post that will take three arugments
    1. The directory where the post should go
    2. The title of the post
    3. A short summary of what the post is about

This function should… 1. use the title to generate a file name that will be the slug like 2020-02-08-my-title.md 1. add the title and the summary to the YAML frontmatter of the file 1. write the file in the directoy specified 1. open my text editor (Emacs) in the directory where I created the file

function new_post() {
  cd ~/$1
  SLUGIFIED="$(echo -n "$2" | sed -e 's/[^[:alnum:]]/-/g' | tr -s '-' | tr A-Z a-z)"
  SLUG=$(date +"%Y-%m-%d"-$SLUGIFIED.md)
  cat <<front_matter > $SLUG
---
layout: post
title: '$2'
summary: '$3'
---

### Words Go Here
front_matter

  emacsclient -t .
}

Learn about the Bash commands used in this function:

  • man echo
  • man sed
  • man tr
  • man date
  • man cat

man is the command to pull up the manual pages for another commands, but you can also use it to learn about itself.

  • man man

Using the function

new_post ~/PairingWithPat/blog/_posts/ "Make this Website" "Learn how this website was made."

Writing the Post

Post contents are written in Markdown

With bundle exec jekyll serve running while I write the post I can see the page refresh on my site and keep an eye on the results to make sure I am formatting my markdown correctly.

Once I am done writing I commit the post to git.

git commit -A
git commit -am 'First draft of first post'

Publishing the Website

Using Github Pages

Project site Start from scratch

Create a repository Copy the git URL Set the repo as a remote

git remote add origin git@github.com:pathouse/non-breaking-space.git

In Gemfile

  1. Remove lines for gem "jekyll" and gem "minima"
  2. Inside group :jekyll_plugins add gem "github-pages"

Then run bundle update

Build the site into the output folder used by Github Pages

jekyll build -d docs

Commit all changes

git add -A
git commit -am 'Deploying with Github Pages'

Push your changes to github

git push origin master

In in the Github Repo go to settings, scroll down to Github pages - select master branch /docs folder as the source for your site

Topic Pages

This theme is built out of the box to handle a standard blog where posts show up in chronological order, but I want to organize the posts on this site into various categories and then group the posts within these categories.

Each category will have an introductory page that includes a list of the posts within that category.

So to do this I am going to make a topic category that is similar to the current home page layout. I am also going to update the home page layout to list these category pages up top.

To create the category layouts we can copy the home page layout but add a filter to the posts to only lists posts from the desired category.

See Liquid Filters documentation on the Jekyll site.


{% assign category_posts = site.posts | where: "category", page.category  %}
{%- for post in category_posts -%}

The entire layout looks like:


<div class="category-page">
  {%- if page.title -%}
  <h1 class="page-heading">{{ page.title }}</h1>
  {%- endif -%}

  {{ content }}

  <h2 class="post-list-heading">Posts</h2>
  <ul class="post-list">
    {% assign category_posts = site.posts | where: "category", page.category  %}
    {%- for post in category_posts -%}
    <li>
      {%- assign date_format = "%b %-d, %Y" -%}
      <span class="post-meta">{{ post.date | date: date_format }}</span>
      <h3>
        <a class="post-link" href="{{ post.url | relative_url }}">
          {{ post.title | escape }}
        </a>
      </h3>
      {%- if site.show_excerpts -%}
      {{ post.excerpt }}
      {%- endif -%}
    </li>
    {%- endfor -%}
  </ul>
</div>

We can save this new layout in _layouts/category_layout.html

Now for each category page we can add the category to the YAML frontmatter.

For example, for the Advent of Code category:

---
layout: post
title: 'AoC - 2015 - Day 1'
summary: 'Working through the first problem in Advent of Code, 2015.'
category: 'aoc'
---

We can make the main category page for Advent of Code in the index as advent-of-code.markdown And setup the YAML frontmatter as follows:

---
layout: category_page
title: 'Advent of Code'
permalink: /advent-of-code/
category: 'aoc'
---

Now we can update the home layout to list the various top level pages. We can copy some code that already does this in _includes/header.html


{%- assign page_paths = site.pages | map: "path" -%}
<h2 class="post-list-heading">Categories</h2>
<ul class="post-list">
{%- for path in page_paths -%}
  {%- assign my_page = site.pages | where: "path", path | first -%}
  {%- if my_page.title -%}
    <li>
      <h3>
        <a class="post-link" href="{{ my_page.url | relative_url }}">{{ my_page.title | escape }}</a>
      </h3>
    </li>
  {%- endif -%}
{%- endfor -%}
</ul>

This is where the power of a static site generator and liquid templating really shines - because now we can have multiple category pages that share this common HTML structure and automatically include new posts in that category without us having to write the same HTML over and over again.
